slides.title: How to Study Effectively (Without Studying More Hours)
slides.subtitle: Practical techniques to learn more in less time
paragraphs: Focus on method, not hours. Build systems that force retrieval, spacing, and targeted practice.

slides.title: The Problem
bullets: Most people 'study,' but don't learn.
Re-reading notes feels productive, but doesn't stick.
Highlighting makes you familiar, not fluent.
Real learning happens when your brain has to retrieve and apply information.
slides.speaker_line: If studying feels easy, it's probably not working.
slides.notes: Emphasize that effortful retrieval creates durable memory. Familiarity is a trap: it feels like learning but fails under test conditions.

slides.title: The 3 Rules of Effective Study
bullets: Active recall: force your brain to pull information out.
Spaced repetition: revisit material over time, not in one big block.
Deliberate practice: target what you get wrong, not what you already know.
slides.speaker_line: These three are the difference between 'I saw it' and 'I can do it.'
slides.notes: Quickly define each rule with one-sentence examples: flashcards for recall, schedule reviews across days for spacing, and error-focused drills for deliberate practice.

slides.title: Active Recall (What to Do)
bullets: Replace passive methods with active techniques:
Blurting: close notes → write everything you remember → check gaps.
Practice questions: use exam-style problems, not summaries.
Teach-back: explain a concept as if tutoring someone.
paragraphs: Quick example: Instead of 'read the chapter,' do: 'Answer 10 questions, then mark and fix errors.'
slides.notes: Give a short demo: show a question, attempt answer aloud, then check. Stress that immediate feedback closes the learning loop.

slides.title: Spacing + Interleaving (How to Schedule)
bullets: Spacing: shorter sessions over multiple days beats cramming.
Day 0: learn.
Day 1: recall.
Day 3: recall again.
Day 7: mixed practice.
Interleaving: mix topics; don't focus on one topic for hours straight.
It feels harder → it works better.
paragraphs: Helps you retrieve the right method under pressure (like in exams).
slides.notes: Explain that making practice harder increases transfer. Use the schedule as a minimal workable plan for most learners.

slides.title: The Feedback Loop (How to Improve Fast)
bullets: After every session, ask: What did I get wrong? Why?
What pattern keeps repeating?
What will I do next session to fix it?
Rule: Your mistakes are your study plan.
Spend 70% of time on weak areas, 30% on review.
slides.notes: Encourage learners to keep a short error log. Over time the log shows recurring misconceptions to prioritize.

slides.title: A Simple 45-Min Study Template (Practical)
bullets: 0–5 min: set a specific goal (target a clear outcome).
5–25 min: active recall / practice questions.
25–35 min: mark answers + write an error log.
35–45 min: re-attempt wrong questions + schedule next review.
slides.speaker_line: No fancy motivation needed—just a system.
slides.notes: This template is repeatable: use it for most short sessions. Emphasize tiny improvements and scheduling the next recall before finishing.

slides.title: Closing
paragraphs: Effective studying isn't about time. It's about technique.
If you do only one change: swap re-reading for retrieval (practice questions + recall), then space it out.
slides.notes: End with a single actionable takeaway: start your next study session with a 10-question self-test instead of rereading.
